Yes, it was erasing and taping over, so I'll just keep on talking now
and go back and start relating the story from where I was born at Remsen, Iowa, October the 7th, 1902.
My folks were living on the farm, as far as I know.
They were farming at that time.
My dad had been a drayman and a policeman in a town of 1,200 with 11 barrooms in it.
Those were the hectic days,
the pioneer days for western Iowa.
However, he farmed for some years.
He had three or four teenage boys at that time, so he thought it best to get out on the farm.
And for some reason or other, some land agent got a hold of him
and suggested that with a gang of boys like he had, he should be up in Canada
where land was cheap and a lot of room for expansion.
At that particular time, land in Iowa was selling,
well, roughly $80 an acre, where you could buy it up in Canada from $20 to $25 an acre.
But it was still the raw prairie.
It had to be broke up and put into cultivation before you could get anything off it.
And I guess they did a good job selling because dad had a lot of courage to move up in that godforsaken country
when he was in a good corn growing,
well-established community down there.
Well, we went up to Canada and they had about three boxcars of, I guess, mostly animals and some machinery.
They didn't have much machinery that you could use up in Canada.
But along with what they took along, they had a boxcar load of it.
And the rest was packed up in the passenger train and headed out.
I don't know the history of whether we—I'm sure we didn't have sleepers.
And we would have had to stop possibly overnight in Minneapolis when we got there.
I don't remember any of that.
I do faintly remember some of the train ride.
And there were—the two boys went with the boxcars of animals.
And they tell of all the fun they had riding in those side door pullmans,
if they call them, along with the animals,
all the way up from Remsen, Iowa, up to Sioux Falls, Sioux City,
and then up what they call the Sioux Line, up to Halbrite.
And landed there on the 17th of March,
after a winter of the greatest snowfall the prairie had ever seen.
There was an estimated 36 inches of snow in Malapa that winter.
However, we landed at Halbrite.
And now this is where my memory starts to get in gear.
We stayed in the hotel.
And I have a faint recollection of us being in this hotel.
This is Mother and all the children.
And then the boys and Dad arrived up there.
Well, I guess Dad was on the train with us.
And the boys came up with the livestock, and they had to unload.
And take it out to the farm.
Now, when they got out there, everything was under snow.
They tell that they had to dig into a snowbank to find the barn, a stable.
And I'd like to see, you know they - just what went on.
These guys coming from Iowa were, if they had six inches of snow there,
it was a big snowfall.
And here they come out with three foot of snow on the level.
We landed in a farm.
Six miles north of Halbrite.
As I remember it, the house stood there for years and years after.
It was a two-bedroom house with a dining room, kitchen combined.
Or a dining room, living room combined, and quite a large kitchen.
And that house stood there for 20, 30 years after we lived in it for the first summer.
And I don't have any recollection of the sleeping arrangements,
where we all slept or anything.
But there were 12 of us.
But the youngest one wasn't born yet.
But there were 12 of us and mother and dad lived in that house.
And I can't figure out, we must have had solid mattresses on the floors
in order to find a place to sleep.
But first I remember the snow was all gone when I remembered that.
I can remember the ride out there with all the deep snow.
All you could see was snow.
As far as the eye could see, everything was white.
And then everything blanks out to me.
The next thing I can remember is that I would have been four and a half years old at that time.
And Liona was just past three, about 14 months younger than I was.
And the two of us walked across the mile where they were building the house on our regular farm
where we were going to live.
And I can remember just a faint recollection.
I guess we sneaked away without authority or anything.
We followed the trail, just a trail over there.
We followed the trail over there.
And the people in the house, they gave us cookies.
And I remember prunes. And Liona ate so many prunes that she had that nickname for years after Prunes Achen.
And then I have no recollection of us moving into that new house.
And that's funny.
And I don't remember, we moved over there that fall before winter set in.
That house was finished.
They put on, the original house was 14 feet by 20 feet with just a bedroom.
The whole upstairs was a bedroom and had a sort of a ladder to get upstairs.
Well, then they put on an extension with three bedrooms on it and a big dining room and a big living room
and a new stairway going up.
So we are well off because we had one of the bigger houses in the community.
And now we're talking into 1905.
I don't think I started school.
I must have been eight or nine years old when I started school.
We used to, we had two schools.
We started at Crow Lake School and that was two miles across the field.
But we had to go around the road.
And it was three miles to Crow Lake.
I can remember starting school there with the Orsted boys in ...
And Joe Barlow, Manning Body.
We were all in grade one.
And we were learning to - the ABCs.
And I think we went there maybe two years.
And for some reason that school was closed down.
And then we went to DeVille School.
That was in the other direction.
Two miles again across
country, no roads.
We went there for, as I remember it, only one year.
And then Crow Lake School opened up again.
And we used to go around the road.
We drove horses the three miles.
And in the summer when they needed the horses in the field,
we walked the three miles.
And then at certain times of the year when it was dry enough,
we'd cut straight across the fields.
And that was just two miles going across that way.
And we used to go a walk, you know the
mosquitoes would be so bad that we'd run to get away from them.
You'd run for a ways and then you'd slow down.
And then when they'd congregate again around you,
you'd run for another stretch -
and that's the way you got your education,
on foot to school and back.
Went there.
And when I was about ten years or twelve years old -
No, I wasn't twelve then,
maybe eleven.
And we were driving.
A single horse on a buggy.
And four or five of us would pile in that one-seated buggy.
Some would stand in the back, stand on the axle.
And an old great big horse that - that drove back and forth.
And then, as I said, in the summertime when they needed them in the fields,
well, we would walk.
Well, I kept up.
That was my education, going to school.
But I will say this much,
when you're in grade, by the time you're in grade four,
you knew the times table.
Not just the four times.
You knew them right up to twelve times.
You knew spelling.
You knew geography.
You've got a good grounding in education.
There's no...
And writing.
They're very particular about your writing.
How you learn to write.
Make the letters, letter perfect, so to speak.
And then I...
Remember when I was about ten years old,
mother and dad took a trip back to Iowa via train.
For some reason, I was picked to go back with them.
I don't know if I was cute or so mean
they couldn't leave me at home or what it was,
but I went to Iowa with them.
I remember quite a bit about that trip,
about being at the various uncles' places.
And there were cousins there my age,
and we used to have a lot of fun playing.
It was in the fall of the year.
And then dad and I came back.
And mother stayed.
For some reason, she stayed.
And dad and I came back,
and I still remember us being in Minneapolis.
And he went down to a bar room
and took me down with him.
And there were all kinds of food.
You could have all the food you wanted for free.
A glass of whiskey at that time,
I guess, was about 25 cents.
And then as we went home that night,
I remember we went
down the street,
and he said,
Take a look down this window.
We looked down a basement window,
and here there were newspaper machines down there,
running all automated newspaper machines.
And the papers were coming out of there
just like nobody's business.
Then I remember going home from Minneapolis,
and dad had me singing.
I could sing pretty good.
Some of the old songs of the day.
And of course I'd sing,
and then everybody would hand me a dime - a dime!
I had dimes,
and I had porters on the train
that were selling candies, oranges, and apples,
and all sorts of good things.
No soft drinks in those days.
But I ate so much of this stuff I got sick,
and I started puking.
And that was the end of the singing.
This train ride to Minneapolis home was about,
oh, I would imagine,
about a 24-hour train ride
to Minneapolis, yes.
It would be, oh, 24 hours
to get from our place up to Minneapolis.
I don't remember anything else then until 19...
Oh, no, not any detail,
except milking cows and doing chores,
and you start doing that
when you're eight years old on the farm.
And at 11 years old,
I rigged up a team of horses on a hay rack,
and I was a straw monkey in the thrashing house.
At 12 years old,
I was out disking the land
with horses while the boys,
all the older ones,
were busy with the thrashing.
I couldn't remember that very well.
And you really had to work
when you were on the farm.
As soon as you were old enough

at five and six years old,
you're out pulling weeds in the garden.
And when I was ... 11,
that would have been 1913,
that's right,
then Sister Aloysia was already
a novice in the convent,
at 14.
And Sister Hilary and I
both went to the convent that winter.
Mary got an education, too.
I was 11 years old.
Well, I...
Yeah, 11 years old,
and I had to do my own laundry.
You were on Saturdays,
you did your own laundry,
you washed your clothes,
got a change of clothes,
took a bath once a week,
I don't remember what bathtubs are.
I think we just took a bath.
The boys had their own room
down in the washroom,
in the laundry room.
We'd take a bath
out of an ordinary wash tub.
The food was plain and simple
and you had to eat
what was put on your plate,
or have a darn good reason
why you didn't eat it.
because you didn't like it,
that you were sick or something
was the only reason
you got away from eating
the food that was put before you.
I remember I was in grade five,
and at Easter time,
we went home,
and I didn't go back.
I don't know why I didn't go back.
I don't remember if Sister Hilary
went back then or not.
But I started school at home,
and I wrote my grade five exam
at home.
Then I must have missed a year,
or I must have failed a grade,
because I went...
I passed my grade six,
I would have been about...
I must have been fourteen
or at least fourteen
or into my fifteenth year.
And then I started school
in grade seven.
Now, I would have been
about fifteen years old
that fall, I guess.
And the teacher and I
couldn't see eye to eye at all.
I guess I was as stubborn
as a fourteen or fifteen-year-old
can be.
And she and I were jangling
all the time as the saying
go:
I was lipping her back
and whatnot.
And I was dissatisfied then,
and I said to Mother one day,
I want to quit school.
What are you going to do?
I said, "I'll go trapping."
You could trap coyotes
and weasels
and what have you.
So she said,

Well, if you don't like school,

I went on the trap line then.

I was doing chores at home.

he got,
I would think he got his grade

During that time,

There's always so much work

It would take you
all forenoon
to get the chores done up.
You had to clean the barns

There was no other way around it.

And then in the afternoon,
I'd go out and I'd set trap
and I'd try to catch the odd weasel,
a weasel skin is worth

a dollar and a quarter.
And there were skunks around

And I caught the odd coyote

twenty dollars.
And so,
I was doing this trapping
on horseback.
I'd get on the old black mare,
old lady,
and I'd ride,
you know,
two or three miles away
from fifteen,
twenty blows zero.
You didn't stop for that.
Go and check your traps
if you caught something
and you brought them home
and you skinned them.
That was,
you kept busy all the time.
There was never a dull moment.
If you had any reading to do,
you did it at night
by coal or a lamp.
And reading wasn't as common
as it is today.
We had no radio at that time.
So you didn't get any news.
You were sort of blanked out,
as they say.
The news you got was
when Dad'd come home from town,
he'd go to town
two or three times a week
and he'd always bring home
all the gossip
from the neighborhood,
you know,
what he had heard.
But we had telephone installed
when I was about twelve,
eleven or twelve years old
when we had the telephone installed.
So you had some communication
with the neighbors,
which was good for the women
in particular.
The boys,
we never talked back and forth.
We had neighbor boys,
but we wanted to talk to them.
We got on a horse
and rode over there,
visited in that way.
And life was simple, very simple.
You worked hard and you ate well, and you slept well.
And the next day, you got up
and it was the same thing over and over.
And to get back to trapping,
after I was trapping for a while,
I found out there was a place in St. Louis, Missouri
where you'd ship your hides.
There was no one duty or anything to get them across the line.
And I found out that you got about half again as much for a coyote skin down there.
So I started shipping them down there -
and skunks the same.
And then I found out
that I'd go out
and I'd buy them
from the neighbors
with the,
they would price them
at what they could get
in the Canadian market
and then I'd ship
to the States
and make myself
a nice profit
maybe a lot of times
50% profit.
I know in one case
I went to a fellow's place,
he had wolfhounds
and he went over there
and he had
10 or 12 coyote skins.
They were in bad shape
they'd been tore up and they were bloody and everything.
And he wanted
$10 a piece for them
and I had another neighbor boy with me
and we went out of there, we had,
I think we had six or seven hides.
Some of them were so bad
I wouldn't buy them.
And they had averaged me $3 a piece.
When I showed them
a few greenbacks
well,
he started
coming around.
I took them down in the dark basement
with the cold oil lamp - lantern
and then I redressed those hides and I put them on a proper stretcher
and got them
the lead washed off them and cleaned up.
The first one I sent away I got
more for it than I'd paid for the whole lot.
And,
well,
that only lasted
so long
and then
this all
happened in about
one winter
that I was dealing
in furs
besides doing
the chores at home.

Well, now I'm into 16 and 17 years old.
The war was on, and it was work, work, work.
Joe and Zip, Joe went in the Army.
Zip was away from home,
he was getting an education.
And I was the main one.
Mac was, what, two and a half years younger than me.
And we always had to do all the chores.
So you worked, worked, and worked.
You would work eight, ten hours a day, every day, in the wintertime as well as in the summer.
Summertime, you worked from
five in the morning until eight at night, every day, six days a week, and then do the chores on Sunday.
We always milked a half dozen cows.
Besides, it was all horse farming in those days.
They had up to 50, 60 horses around the farm that you had to look after.
In the summer when I was, what, 1915, I was 13 years old that fall.
Yeah, this is hard to believe.
And Joe and Zip were home that summer.
And the three of us hauled rock and gravel all summer.
Had three wagons and horses.
And we'd used to go 13 miles down to the river to get three loads of sand, load them up, and take them home.
By the time we got home, we'd leave at, say, 7 or 8 in the morning.
By the time we got home, it was 4 in the afternoon.
And you had to unload your load,
and then do the chores, and then be ready to make the trip the next day.
And this went on, I guess, for two months that we were hauling material to build this big barn.
It was a huge barn.
The foundation was 56 feet one way and 60 feet the other way.
And then the contractor came in and he built the barn.

he put down the foundation everything then we had to haul all those rock in to fill that foundation in and then filled it up with sand so they could put a four inch coat of cement all over the barn it was an up-to-date barn everything was first class. That's when I was 13 years old that fall, the fall of 1915. You want to know about work, well that was work and that same
The year before that, yeah, we didn't have a decent well on the farm.
My brother Mac and I, he would have been about ten, I guess.
We were hauling water with a team of horses and a big wooden tank.

We used to have to go two and a half miles up to where there was a pond and get this water and then haul it down and dump it in the big tank in the pasture where there were about, oh, there would have been three, four hundred
head of cattle in that 1,500-acre pasture.
And that went on until we finally got a well at home that wouldn't go dry, and then we didn't have to haul water anymore.
We didn't have to pump it.
They'd pump it into the tank and haul it down.
Somebody else finally took that job over.
We probably had to go to school when the school term started.
I don't remember the detail.
But that gives you an idea of how hard we worked when we were young.
I often said, I don't know what all the help -
I was the seventh son, and Mac was the eighth one.

with a postal order, and they'd come and pick us up at night.
We'd have our lunch with us out there, but the bald prairie, no trees or no shade or anything, just out there working.
And you'd get so tired that you'd stop and snare golfers once in a while, just for getting a little bit of a rest.
Well, that's
through the 1914, '15, '16, it was the same thing.

And short on help.
I wasn't going to school then.
Work, work, work.
1917, bad, kind of a bad year.
1916, yeah.
Then, '17 is a short crop, '18 was a short crop.

The fall of '23, Mother had gone to California.
Yes, she went by herself.
And Leona stayed home to keep house.
It was Mac and Leona and I.
Bud was away to the convent.
Dad was there with us.
And Dad and I were hauling grain.
We had a big crop that year, and we were hauling grain.
There was no snow.
We were hauling with wagons all winter.
And he always complained that he wasn't feeling well.
I would go and load the grain after the chores was done in the morning.
I would load the grain, and then he and I would haul it to town.
Slow process.
A team of horses moving at about three miles an hour.
So it took you about three hours to make the trip, or more than that, four hours to make the trip to town and back.

We kept that up.
Finally, he said one day, "I'm going up to Griffin to see the doctor."
When he came home, I said, "What did the doctor say?"
Oh, the doctor said, just a broken down old piece of machinery.
So he accepted that and kept on going.
And a couple of weeks later, he still wasn't feeling well, so he went to Kenmare, North Dakota, where there were some renowned doctors.
And he was gone.
a week, and we hadn't heard anything from him, or of him, I should say.
And finally we got a card that he had been admitted to the hospital as a patient.
And following that, the next day we got a phone call that somebody had better come down.
He's a pretty sick man.
So I caught the train that night.
I didn't have any money or anything.
I went to the banker, and the banker was a good friend of Dad's.
So he gave me money to make the trip.
When I got to Kenmare about two o'clock in the morning, well, I phoned the hospital and they said he was resting fine.
And the next morning when I got up and I went to the hospital and I got there, they said, "Your dad just passed away."
So there I was with a dead father and didn't know which way to turn.
So I phoned back up to Halbrite and talked to my Aunt Mary.
And she sort of directed me to let the relatives in Iowa know about her mother in California.
And by that time, she had worked her way up to Oregon, was staying with my sister Emma.
So we got a hold of her there, and I went back home.
We had the body shipped back to Halbrite for burial, and

mother,  mother got there by train it's funny how you could move around in those days. She'd come all the way from portland and we only held the funeral two days, I think. She was there for the funeral. And then I was in charge of the farm starting right then and there so that was in 1924 and uh
Mac and I run the farm.
Bud was there.
Leona was there, but she went to California that winter again, so we were alone with Mother.
'25, good crop.
'26, good crop.
'26, some of the boys came up from California, and they thought Mother was paying me too much money.

Brother Mac took over the farm.
That was the fall of '26.

And in that came Christmas Day, Boxing Day, and the Sunday and all, and they wanted to go out and work right straight through until it was finished.
And I said, "That's going to cost you a lot of money, a lot of overtime in there for the amount of work we do."
That don't make any difference.
But when I present them with a bill, "Oh, we can't stand that overtime.
No way."
The guy, the engineer in charge said, "If I presented that, I said, my job could be on the,

on the line." And he said, "You're going to have to cut back and stand half that overtime yourself." Which meant that I made damn little on the job but that's the way - They would take advantage of you occasionally when they got you over the barrel.
All in all, I will have to say they treated me pretty fair I had - I had a lot of leeway with them and with this man Durnan,

we had a lot of trust in each other although, he was a tight one. Boy, he wouldn't - he'd give you authority to do things but don't ever try to to pad the invoice or anything like that or he'd be right on you in a minute.
But it all went on and on. While that was going on, I think I related earlier that, I had an outfit working in the city for 10 years that equipment: a boring machine,
a pole truck - pole trailer, and a two-ton truck.
And they were on so much an hour.
And in those 10 years, I never raised the rate on that.
I only raised wages as they went along.
I took 10% on payroll.
Well, that was sort of a meal ticket for me.
And then when they'd get behind, I could leave the work stack up and bring in my men from the field in the fall when they were finished out there.
And then we'd pick up a lot of extra work in the city.
I set all the poles in all the suburbs that were built from 1951.
Yes, I even did some in 1945 or '46.
And then started again in '50.
Set all the poles and built all the lines in all the suburbs in Regina.
That takes in Lakeview, Albert Park, Whitmore Park,
Douglas Park, Norman, what's the one up northwest?
Not Normanview.
Yeah, we did that too.
We did everything until, as long as it was overhead, we were doing it.
And once it started going underground, then they started putting their own outfits in.
And then we were also involved in that through the years, but not in a big way.
But for 10 years, I
I had this deal with Nichols, and the superintendent phoned me up one day and asked me what I would take to do some work for them, and I quoted him over the telephone.
He said, "Put that out in a letter and send it to me."
And I sent it to him, and about seven years later, he phoned back.
He said, "Hey, have you got anything, a copy of the deal we made when you started working for the city?"
I said, "Yeah, I've got the letter in the file here somewhere."
Well, he said, "I wish you'd send me a copy of it.
I can't find my copy of the letter.
I've been asked some questions regarding your work in here."
And he said, "I want to show it to him that we had a contract."
So that was it until it finally petered out gradually.
And that was it -
Boy, it was a sort of a mail ticket for me through those ten years.
I always had that steady work coming in in the city.
It wasn't big, but it took up the slack, so to speak.
Steady income.
And what were some of the other things now?
I'll have to just think for a moment of other things that may be of interest to you fellows.
Oh yes, speaking of some of the laws of the game, they always said a business, a company can't stay in business unless they expand.
Well, we virtually broke that law.
We never really expanded.
Well, after the first five years I expanded a bit and then went static from there.
I had a basic crew.
I built an office and a shop in '53, and it was too small the day I built it, and it's still operating.
Now we're up to 35 years later and still getting along with that same shop.
I did put an extension on the office.
I expanded the office in 1958, I think it was,
made some storage room upstairs, and more office space in front which gave us more room in the shop.
But again, we broke the law that you can't operate -
Art took over, and I figured right away he's going to have to move into bigger quarters, but up till this day they're still making that same shop do the job.
I guess the proof in the pudding is the observation of it, that the company has always been sound financially and making money and making things do,
That's the biggest thing.
I've seen these shops, you know, with five or six stalls in them.
The Power Corporation were that way.
They'd have five or six stalls and everything standing there and nothing happening.
And when they wanted something overhauled, they'd come down and say, can you get this ready for us tomorrow?
We've got to have this
a trenching machine going tomorrow.
And my fellows would run in the shop and go in maybe and work out on the night and have it going for them.
And their shop, everything was standing still.
Well, they were unionized.
The guy that turned, that cracked the wrench, he couldn't "jack the vehicle up", so to speak.
Nobody ever knew what it cost them to do their repair work.
It was so extensive they never even kept track of it.
That was one of the rules of the game that we built - we wrote.
So Art and the boys took over, I thought, now they're going to show the old man how to run an outfit.
Do you know that they never changed one thing?
The same principles still apply after 21 years that were being used when I was there, excepting
I had an old man for a bookkeeper.
When he died, I got another old man.
And Art got George Jenny's wife.
She had taken a business course.
She came in, and she was a crackerjack of a bookkeeper.
She was worth her weight in gold.
I said, "If I'd had one like that, maybe I wouldn't have quit business, because she really took a lot of load off in the office."
And Art put in a, he was always a great guy for gadgets, he put in a second-handed computer that cost him $1,500.
And he would use it for payroll and for keeping track of accounts, one thing or another.
And then after that, he got rid of that and he put one in for $10,000.
And he was using that.
But I still kid them.
I said, "Why do you have to have a computer?"
I said, "I had a man 80 years old making the payroll,

doing all the books and everything was always up to date he'd be a little late if I asked for a cutoff to see how we were doing." I said, "Sometimes it would take him 30 days to give me a cutoff but I question if they can do it any faster with a computer."
But Art liked gadgets and he got computers. He even got a small one in his bedroom at home and he does a lot of fiddling around with that.
He - he was one of the men with more ability than anybody I

probably ever run across. He could do anything. He could overhaul anything. He could fix anything if they had hydraulic trouble on any machines even the competitors would bring their machines in and have him fix the hydraulics on them which, sometimes when you get a lot of hydraulics on a machine it can become pretty tricky. And weld anything,
diagnose anything motor troubles or anything like that. He could pick it off just like a real expert.

And, computer - he could program a computer. He did all his own programming and the computers were most outfits hire a guy to come and do that. Art, he said, "I know what I want" and he would program the computer.
He said, or claimed that, prices changed so much that unless you had a computer to keep track of it, that you couldn't keep up to it, doing it in longhand.
That was when you were buying equipment and reselling it, and buying repairs, keeping track of your repairs.
But I question very much - another girl -
Of course, if you're going to spend $15,000 for a computer or have to spend that much for another girl, you might as well have a computer and let a computer do the work if you can.
And that's another thing that in the computer age, I guess you've got to go with it whether you like it or not.

I get a kick out of when I go down to buy a cup of coffee and to watch what a performance the girl goes through to ring up a 55 cent cup of coffee, and how that machine has to work. And she punches buttons like playing a Hammond organ to ring up a cup of coffee, and I said, "Is all that necessary?" "Well, it's got to go through the computer." she says.
I suppose they know exactly how much they make on a cup of coffee.
That could be important if you're selling enough cups.
Well, now that it's all over, I reminisce in my mind some of the things that happened in the past years.
I made a lot of friends in the business, a lot of business friends in Regina.

How fast, now in 20 years or going on to 22 years, it's all disappearing, going over in the horizon. Your friends are dying off, they're moving away, things are, what shall we say, retirement isn't what you imagined it would be. It's all been a different life altogether than I thought it would be. I thought we old-timers that were in the business would be getting together and would have coffee.
You know that there's not one power man that I have coffee with.
I have coffee with telephone guys and farmers and bookkeepers and railroaders and everything, but not one of the old power men around here anymore.
If they are, they don't show up for coffee.
Oh, once in a while you'll meet one, but not the old pals that I had.
I think I mentioned earlier that
my real close friends, Jack Bell, Harold Huntington, and Al Wakemore.
Harold and Al died long ago, and Jack Bell has moved up to Edmonton.
So those were my real close friends.
And many of my other good friends that I had in business. They're down in the area where I am, they've passed on.
There's not many of them around.
A fellow called me the other day, that I used to have coffee with regularly.
I hadn't seen him for, I guess, for 15 years.
He said, "We've got to get together someday and have coffee."
I said, "Yeah, a real good idea."
He had a business right back to back.
Our business places were back to back for 15 years.
But it's all changed, all different.
You have to adjust,

sort of live from week to week, month to month, and year to year. Change, accept what comes, make the most of it. One thing that I can say is that i've enjoyed relatively good health I haven't been - outside of my operation a year ago, a little over a year ago,
I've enjoyed relatively good health, considering that when I quit, I - when I quit in 1965, I was pretty well burned out.
I didn't have any more giddy-up-and-go in me, and that's why I got out of the business.
I said, "It's just getting too tough to come down here every day and keep this outfit going."
While I was making good money, I said, "If I don't get out of here, you'll carry me out in a basket."
I've never regretted that I got out when I did, and I've never regretted -

In fact, I'm glad that the boys have done well and kept the thing going, and the name Achen is still on the building, and they're still operating under Achen Construction, which to me was one of the highlights, that they thought enough of me to use the name.
We had a good reputation, and they said,
Can we use the name?
They asked for permission.
And I said, "Yes, I'll grant you the permission to use the name that much.
No strings attached." Except they made it Achen Construction, 1965 Limited.
They just changed the name.
An awful lot of people still think I run the company because they see the name, and they never even noticed that the changeover took place.
And those are some of the
the good things that come back to you.

I have to have mentioned that the high praise I have for the men that worked for me, the key men that I kept around there. There were six, eight of them, that they were working for me all the time, and that's what made the company go.
And this man Miller, while he was an oddball, in some ways, he was
just ace high as an employee. There wasn't - He was a guy that never said no.
In the 20 years that we worked together I never raised my voice to him and he never raised his voice to me.
If we had any discussions they were done in the just in an ordinary tone of voice and and that held no matter how big the difference was or or anything, we'd just talk it over and well
make a decision, go one way or the other, or go halfway between.
And that was a wonderful thing.
Although there were times when I tried to crowd more load onto him, and I had a hell of a time to get him to take over the responsibility of the equipment.
I'd want a couple of new trucks.
I'd say, "Go out and buy a couple of new trucks, Art."
And by God, he'd
Hum - hum-haw around, hum-haw around, get prices.
Then he'd come back to me and say, "Which ones should we buy?"
I said, "Art, I don't give a damn which ones you buy."
I said, "You're the guy that's going to have to look after them.
There isn't a hundred dollars difference in the price.
Get the truck that you want."
The same with overhauling equipment.
Boring machines need repairs.
He'd come in to me and say, "What should we do?"
Whatever you think.
I said, "If you think you want to spend $1,000 fixing that thing up, go ahead and fix it.
If you want to do it for $500, do it for $500.
You're the guy who's got to keep it running."
And eventually he got that he would take the responsibility.
But that took several years before I could get him to - Well, I suppose he felt he was spending my money and he wanted my permission.
And after he took over,
well he had no problem.
When I went down there, it wasn't to make any decisions.
It was estimating, to help him estimate.
And he had done a lot of estimating.
We used to both estimate a job.
And I had trained him on estimating.
And he had his method of doing it, and I had mine.
And it was amazing how we could estimate a job that would save $50,000 or $100,000 and come out
with almost the exact figure, but both used a different method of arriving at that figure.
But he was probably like I was.
He could multiply man hours, or so many men could do so much work, and you multiply that down to unit prices, how much per unit.
I'll relate some of the things, though, what experience does for you.
When he joined up with this fellow from Yorkton, and they were taking on some big jobs.
They were bidding on a job up in, oh, way up in Alaska - Northwest Territories - north of Whitehorse, wherever Whitehorse is.
And I had looked at it on a map, a great big map, and saw the route and everything, and talked to Art.
They went up and looked at it
and come back, and I talked to him and found out what the terrain was and everything.
There were three of them, an outfit from Saskatoon, and Art, and this other fellow from Yorkton were going to bid on it jointly.
And they were up in the hotel doing the estimating, that was it.
And they had worked on it three days, and they phoned me at the office.
I was running the office for Art while he was up there.
Phoned the office, "Come on up for happy hour.
We're finished."
So I go up there and I walked in the door. The - the secretary of the outfit, the bookkeeper from Saskatoon.
He said, "How much you want for building that line, Lindy?"
And I said, "I would want $1,980,000 to do that job."
He said, is that complete?
I said, yeah.
He said, "My God, he said, we've been sitting here for three days figuring, and you're within $10,000 of what we came up with for a figure."
He said, "How did you get that figure?"
I said, "Just dead reckoning."
I said, "I talked over with Art what the terrain was like and everything, and it was a rough country, and a big job."
You had to haul the material along -"
I said, "That's what..."
Then another time they bid right in the office.
This fellow from Yorkton and Art would do the job, and they're bidding on stringing a second circuit from Regina to Estevan.
That's a hundred and, what is it, a hundred and twenty-five or thirty miles.
One side of the line was hot and you had to string the other side.
This was on big steel towers.
And I walked in and this Glen Thorpe guy from Yorkton said,
How much for building that line, or stringing that line, Lindy?
I said, "$1,250 a tower."
He looked at me.
He said, "Cripes, that's just what we figured out.
We've been sitting here three days."
Well, I said, "That's - I figured out.
I said, What would it take to string that line?
And that's what I came up with."
Another time, they were doing a job at Swift Current.
And it was an odd job.
It had to be done while the river was froze over, and they had to put three 90-foot poles on an island.
Oh, it was a hell of a job.
And I had looked at the blueprint.
I took a look at that, and I said, "So many men, so many men here."
So this is what I said to myself.
So when they...
They had to figure it out.
I said, "How much you figure for that, that island job?"
They said $24,000.
Now, you're going to do that job separately.
Let me know who's the closest when you're finished.
They never did let me know whether I was right.
And I have a notion that I was right and they were wrong or that they'd been bringing it up to me.
Well, those are some of the things you get a big kick out of.
Guesstimation, I guess. Guesstimation.
Another time we had built a line up in Alberta, I may have said that earlier. And Art Miller was up there. This was way back in '49.

And they couldn't get this line to stay in. It would kick out the fuses as fast they put them in and they had worked - all the engineers from the Canadian Utilities were out there and they couldn't find the trouble. Art phoned me at night
I said, "I'll tell you what you do in the morning.
You drive way out to the far end of that line where you cross that big ravine.
You probably find the wires twisted there."
He said, "Why do you say that?"
Because, I said, "I drove over that line once." And I said, "This would be a beautiful place to have a buck in the wire because you're looking at the trees and you can't see it."
The next day he phoned at Noon
and he said, "You were right."
He said, "The wires were bucked up there."
He said, "We all looked pretty silly, and then phoned you, and you tell us where the trouble -
They had driven the line and hadn't seen it, because you looked into the trees, you couldn't see it.
And when they went back and took a second look at it, they found out that's where the trouble was.
A lot of times they'd phone in from the country.
They were up at Elrose, hooking up a town, and they had trouble.
Funny things were happening to them, and I'm sitting
at home and they phoned me and "Well," I said, "What's happening?" And they told me. I told them what to look for and they found the trouble and that was it.
Oh when they had the same thing happen, that was about three years later, the same thing happened but a different foreman, and he couldn't figure out his trouble.
Then they sort of think you're a wise guy. you know. You come along and a machine isn't working. I come along, the boring machine was in a garage and
the guy had changed the carburetor, he changed the coils, he did everything, and the motor wouldn't start.
I said, "Take that switch plate off back here, where you turn the switch on."
Took it off, the wires were disconnected in there.
Well - And they all looked at you, you know.
They'd go, "You're smart.".
Well, it's just a process of elimination.
They had tried everything else, but they hadn't tried that, so you tell them to try that.
Oh, I had a guy, Ray Booth, he used to shake his head.
He said, "How can you figure these things out?"
I said, "Process of elimination.
That's all it is.
You ask the other guy what he's done first and he's done everything else, then you think of something he hasn't done, that's probably where the trouble is."
So that's the way it went from - a lifetime in power from 1928 to 1965.
And then I wasn't finished.
I still had my finger in the pie till about 1975.
And since that, not much has...
They haven't called on me very often.
They've found out how to... Well, five years ago Art had trouble.
He couldn't find the trouble.
It was in a big government garage.
And again, I told him what to look for, and that's where he found the trouble.
And I said, "It can't be anything else."
They were looking in the substation.
I was looking in the substation and all was right in the building.
So that's the way it goes.
I don't know how many more years I'll be here to reminisce, but I'm -
Every once in a while I get a smile when I think back to some of the things that happened.

When I started out paying a laborer 40 cents an hour and he paid his own room and board, and now the minimum wage is $3.60 an hour, and you have to pay the room and board, and you pay holiday pay and everything.
None of that was on the books when I started out.
You have so many things that have changed.
And people have become less reliable, too.
I've found the more money they get, the less they give a damn.
I don't know what it would be like if I'd be running an outfit now.
Some of the old-timers tell me, I wish you'd be out here sometime and straighten things out.
I see what happens around here now compared to what happened when you were there.
Well, I said, "I probably wouldn't be able to do much about it. The laws of change and the rules and regulations have changed, and you've got to go along with it.
So I suppose after you listen to this you may have a lot of questions to ask me.
To the women, the girls this may not be of much interest, but Danny and Norm should get something out of it. They both worked out on the job."
Not - not a lot, but enough to get a smattering of what goes on. And, they should get - Not Norm, so much, he - he's in the banking end of it.
But, Danny should. He's just starting out in life. I was about his age when I started in the power business, and -
And it doesn't come fast it comes one day at a time, one week at a time, one month at a time ,one year at a time, and
the main thing is that you're always bettering your own position.
Use the old saying, day by day, in every way, I'm getting better and better.
And that will help you as you go along.
When people see you, that you're the boss of the job, you hardly ever get there overnight.
That's a long process to get up there.
I was probably one of the lucky ones.
And the fact that when I was home, I was put in charge of things from the time I was 19 years old.
My dad died when I was 21, so I was in full charge of the farm for the three years.
I worked on power lines, less than two years when I was made a foreman and was never anything less than that throughout my total career. So it -
It doesn't fall that easy for everyone.
Some have to work years and years and years to get up the ladder.
But I can say this, I never went to work in my life when I wasn't anxious to get to the job and meet the challenge of the day, regardless of what it was.
And with that, I will say, "Over and out."
